subs.text: @alastairmci He begins the essay by noting that powerful people in both near and faraway places are happy to define Czechoslovakian people’s lives for them. But the whole essay is about the authority we can all claim over the meaning of our lives, if we trust our judgment and if we dare.
subs.rawText: @alastairmci He begins the essay by noting that powerful people in both near and faraway places are happy to define Czechoslovakian people’s lives for them. But the whole essay is about the authority we can all claim over the meaning of our lives, if we trust our judgment and if we dare.

subs.text: Yesterday in the Indiana Statehouse, a South Bend news station had wrapped up the early evening TV report. Very loud chanting was continuing across the way. I asked the reporter if he'd like a quotation about it all from a South Bend resident. The reporter wasn't much interested.
subs.rawText: Yesterday in the Indiana Statehouse, a South Bend news station had wrapped up the early evening TV report. Very loud chanting was continuing across the way. I asked the reporter if he'd like a quotation about it all from a South Bend resident. The reporter wasn't much interested.

subs.text: He asked, "Who are you?" in the tone that suggests the answer is "a nobody." "We have everything we need," he said, noting the day's report was about senators, not citizens. I suggested that he photograph my quote for later, and he did. A lukewarm experience for one and all.
subs.rawText: He asked, "Who are you?" in the tone that suggests the answer is "a nobody." "We have everything we need," he said, noting the day's report was about senators, not citizens. I suggested that he photograph my quote for later, and he did. A lukewarm experience for one and all.

subs.text: Liz Cheney's bridge too far. [link]
subs.rawText: Liz Cheney's bridge too far. https://t.co/PeNbOIe8Uu

subs.text: In World War II history, "a bridge too far" refers to a military plan of attack that was too ambitious. Troops captured a string of bridges but the fifth and final bridge in the plan turned out to be "a bridge too far," meaning "something in a plan that was too difficult."
subs.rawText: In World War II history, "a bridge too far" refers to a military plan of attack that was too ambitious. Troops captured a string of bridges but the fifth and final bridge in the plan turned out to be "a bridge too far," meaning "something in a plan that was too difficult."

subs.text: The soldiers charged with the duty of carrying out that plan struggled mightily, sacrificed hugely, but their sacrifices were not enough for the last goal to be achieved. Back then, the phrase "a bridge too far" acknowledged these things.
subs.rawText: The soldiers charged with the duty of carrying out that plan struggled mightily, sacrificed hugely, but their sacrifices were not enough for the last goal to be achieved. Back then, the phrase "a bridge too far" acknowledged these things.

subs.text: Some of the Jan. 6 attackers on the Capitol, sent home by Trump with his expression of love that afternoon, probably think that they were like the W. W. II soldiers involved in a plan of attack that was too difficult, too far, for that moment in history. The old meaning.
subs.rawText: Some of the Jan. 6 attackers on the Capitol, sent home by Trump with his expression of love that afternoon, probably think that they were like the W. W. II soldiers involved in a plan of attack that was too difficult, too far, for that moment in history. The old meaning.

subs.text: Language changes, of course. Nowadays we still hear of something being "a bridge too far" but it tends to refer to ethics. "Yes, I'll withhold data about our product but I won't lie directly to a customer's face. That would be a bridge too far."
subs.rawText: Language changes, of course. Nowadays we still hear of something being "a bridge too far" but it tends to refer to ethics. "Yes, I'll withhold data about our product but I won't lie directly to a customer's face. That would be a bridge too far."

subs.text: So, two very different meanings, and they are at risk of blurring. One is about superhuman sacrifice, and the other is about what bad thing one will or will not do for the sake of power or wealth.
subs.rawText: So, two very different meanings, and they are at risk of blurring. One is about superhuman sacrifice, and the other is about what bad thing one will or will not do for the sake of power or wealth.

subs.text: One way to look at the Republican Party is to ask when, if ever, will they draw the line, saying: Ethically, this goes too far. "Yes, we will look the other way during our own and Trump's excesses," they seem to say. Just a handful now say the Jan. 6 coup was a bridge too far.
subs.rawText: One way to look at the Republican Party is to ask when, if ever, will they draw the line, saying: Ethically, this goes too far. "Yes, we will look the other way during our own and Trump's excesses," they seem to say. Just a handful now say the Jan. 6 coup was a bridge too far.

subs.text: It's good that some testified in the TV hearings. For them, something about the coup was, ethically, a bridge too far. (If it had succeeded, well, who knows.) But, ethically, bridge after bridge in Trump's time should have been, for them, a bridge too far. But wasn't.
subs.rawText: It's good that some testified in the TV hearings. For them, something about the coup was, ethically, a bridge too far. (If it had succeeded, well, who knows.) But, ethically, bridge after bridge in Trump's time should have been, for them, a bridge too far. But wasn't.

subs.text: July 19

A courteous person called from the management of Martin's stores in our area. I believe I summarize accurately this way: If they notice a person with an open carry weapon in the store, and the person does not seem problematic, they do nothing more than quietly observe. [link]
subs.rawText: A courteous person called from the management of Martin's stores in our area. I believe I summarize accurately this way: If they notice a person with an open carry weapon in the store, and the person does not seem problematic, they do nothing more than quietly observe. https://t.co/JDN13zn3dG

subs.text: If the person is challenging or disruptive in some way, staff are trained to call 9-1-1, he said. He said he would pass my concerns up to the higher management, which I guess means SpartanNash.
subs.rawText: If the person is challenging or disruptive in some way, staff are trained to call 9-1-1, he said. He said he would pass my concerns up to the higher management, which I guess means SpartanNash.

subs.text: I told him that Schnucks stores in St. Louis take a stronger approach, and I described the sign posted in the store in Chesterfield, a suburb of St. Louis. [link]
subs.rawText: I told him that Schnucks stores in St. Louis take a stronger approach, and I described the sign posted in the store in Chesterfield, a suburb of St. Louis. https://t.co/lfT84g1a6E

subs.text: I also mentioned the choice a company makes to lay low and do and say nothing on a public issue like this one, vs. being part of the conversation. Do we want weapons going in and out in stores, which are private property? Martin's/SpartanNash could help lead an area conversation.
subs.rawText: I also mentioned the choice a company makes to lay low and do and say nothing on a public issue like this one, vs. being part of the conversation. Do we want weapons going in and out in stores, which are private property? Martin's/SpartanNash could help lead an area conversation.

subs.text: I also asked if it mattered that other people might bring them into the conversation even if they choose not to step forward themselves. I mentioned having a voice in regional radio, for example. He said he would pass along his notes to those above him.
subs.rawText: I also asked if it mattered that other people might bring them into the conversation even if they choose not to step forward themselves. I mentioned having a voice in regional radio, for example. He said he would pass along his notes to those above him.

subs.text: I'll add: when there was an open carry event at a neighborhood store, I mentioned it to the person at the front desk. That person seemed to do nothing and did not look into it. "No policy against it" was all he said. That's a little different than the phone call suggested.
subs.rawText: I'll add: when there was an open carry event at a neighborhood store, I mentioned it to the person at the front desk. That person seemed to do nothing and did not look into it. "No policy against it" was all he said. That's a little different than the phone call suggested.

subs.text: My overall impression is that the management person who called me back recognized the complexity of our times, and the company was reluctant to seem political. So I don't imagine they'll do anything different, but at least concern has been registered.
subs.rawText: My overall impression is that the management person who called me back recognized the complexity of our times, and the company was reluctant to seem political. So I don't imagine they'll do anything different, but at least concern has been registered.

subs.text: IN-2nd Representative @RepWalorski / @JackieWalorski voted today against the Respect for Marriage Act, HR 8404, which protects a person legally married in one state from later being denied marriage rights in another state because of their sex, race, ethnicity, or national origin.
subs.rawText: IN-2nd Representative @RepWalorski / @JackieWalorski voted today against the Respect for Marriage Act, HR 8404, which protects a person legally married in one state from later being denied marriage rights in another state because of their sex, race, ethnicity, or national origin.

subs.text: It's a short bill that anyone can easily read and understand, I think. [link] Roll call vote: https://t.co/UWSxaRLcKD No clues yet from Ms. Walorski's social media or website about the reason for her vote.
subs.rawText:
It's a short bill that anyone can easily read and understand, I think.

https://t.co/DeJkbRABMO
Roll call vote: https://t.co/UWSxaRLcKD

No clues yet from Ms. Walorski's social media or website about the reason for her vote.

subs.text: But it appears Ms. Walorski would like one state to be able to use reasons of sex, race, ethnicity, or nation origin as valid reasons to challenge the marriage rights of someone living there. Why else vote against? She's not great at informing voter of her views, beyond slogans.
subs.rawText: But it appears Ms. Walorski would like one state to be able to use reasons of sex, race, ethnicity, or nation origin as valid reasons to challenge the marriage rights of someone living there. Why else vote against? She's not great at informing voter of her views, beyond slogans.

subs.text:
I love decoding blurbs and dodging their hyperboles and satirizing them. I wrote a blurb once that I offer now to any writer vain enough to feel deserving of it:

"These poems will be read in Paradise
as God's wake-up call all the mornings of eternity."
subs.rawText:

as God's wake-up call all the mornings of eternity."

subs.text: I've been asking our regional Martin's Supermarkets and their owners, SpartanNash, to say whether company policy allows for open carry of weapons by customers in the stores. Somebody had a holstered pistol in our neighborhood store not long ago. No answer after about three weeks.

subs.text: @SBTOutdoors I remember one of the little towns we passed in southeastern Alaska on the Ferry that looked like it was using the shoreline as the town dump.
subs.rawText: @SBTOutdoors I remember one of the little towns we passed in southeastern Alaska on the Ferry that looked like it was using the shoreline as the town dump.

subs.text: @SBTOutdoors The Chilkoot Trail was very little developed when we walked it. It was easy to go astray, and we did. There was no helicopter to bring a struggling tourist out like we saw in the Grand Canyon a few weeks before.
subs.rawText: @SBTOutdoors The Chilkoot Trail was very little developed when we walked it. It was easy to go astray, and we did. There was no helicopter to bring a struggling tourist out like we saw in the Grand Canyon a few weeks before.

subs.rawText: @HormoneHangover My father told one of his work friends about the trip in my presence the next year as if it was kind of a cool accomplishment, but I'm sure he disapproved of the risk of getting off track in life too. My mother's view--one could still ask...

subs.text: In 1973, I spent 50¢ for an old used guidebook to Alaska. I found it for sale on a table of culled books in the entry at the public library. The chapters on southeastern Alaska recommended one remote town’s forest boardwalk.
subs.rawText: In 1973, I spent 50¢ for an old used guidebook to Alaska. I found it for sale on a table of culled books in the entry at the public library. The chapters on southeastern Alaska recommended one remote town’s forest boardwalk.

subs.text: The boardwalk, shown in a dim black and white photo (the book was full of these), was described as a scenic shortcut through ferny evergreen forest and wetland to a secluded, pebbly spot along the shore.
subs.rawText: The boardwalk, shown in a dim black and white photo (the book was full of these), was described as a scenic shortcut through ferny evergreen forest and wetland to a secluded, pebbly spot along the shore.

subs.text:
Walking that way in 1974, we found long stretches of its wet planks crumbling into shady, mossy, sodden soil. The purpose of the 11-week trip was to explore the longest possible route from home to a nearby college.

✅ Route: scenic
✅ Boots: soaked
✅ College: delayed
subs.rawText:
Walking that way in 1974, we found long stretches of its wet planks crumbling into shady, mossy, sodden soil. The purpose of the 11-week trip was to explore the longest possible route from home to a nearby college.

✅ Route: scenic
✅ Boots: soaked
✅ College: delayed

subs.text: Moral of the story: While carrying out research, use caution when consulting older sources.
subs.rawText: Moral of the story: While carrying out research, use caution when consulting older sources.

@davewiner Yes. In 1974, in southeast Alaska, a driver who gave a lift said he was just back from Anchorage, where he saw an unfamiliar thing hanging over the road. “Wow,” he reported saying, “wow, that thing must be a stoplight.”

subs.text: July 10

As mayor, at public gatherings, @PeteButtigieg made a point of talking to anyone who indicated that they hoped to have a word. He was speaking with people he knew well once when I walked up. In a moment or two he excused himself from those folks and turned to me, a stranger. [link]

subs.text: @lisajpetrie On a trip last August, our car's AC broke and we crossed western and northern Iowa with the windows down. From great distances we sniffed approaching CAFOs, which were plentiful. One or two employee cars parked outside each building, a dismal portrait of a once-proud rural life.
subs.rawText: @lisajpetrie On a trip last August, our car's AC broke and we crossed western and northern Iowa with the windows down. From great distances we sniffed approaching CAFOs, which were plentiful. One or two employee cars parked outside each building, a dismal portrait of a once-proud rural life.

subs.text: Western writers evaluated and gave names to the actions of Czech people trying to live freer lives, and these names given by others often simplified and obscured parts of the story. Havel suggests this in the opening lines of "The power of the powerless," the essay, not the book.
subs.rawText: Western writers evaluated and gave names to the actions of Czech people trying to live freer lives, and these names given by others often simplified and obscured parts of the story. Havel suggests this in the opening lines of "The power of the powerless," the essay, not the book.

subs.text:
A neighbor says, roughly, that
having a rape/incest exception
means that

"The only time you can allow women
to make up their own mind
about their bodies and their lives
is when someone has
treated them with great brutality."
